author: Postmedia News
title: Pot activists Marc and Jodie Emery arrested in Toronto as police raid their marijuana dispensaries
text:
Prominent marijuana activists Marc and Jodie Emery have been arrested in Toronto and police are raiding several pot dispensaries associated with the couple.
Lawyer Jack Lloyd says the couple was taken into custody at Toronto’s Pearson International Airport on Wednesday evening.
Neither Lloyd nor Toronto police could confirm what, if any, charges the Emerys are facing. Lloyd says the Emerys are due in a Toronto courtroom on Thursday.
The couple own the Cannabis Culture brand, which is used by a chain of marijuana dispensaries in British Columbia, Ontario and Quebec.
Quick vid outside @CannabisCulture in #Vancouver . Not much happening, just saw officer enter with bolt cutters. pic.twitter.com/4rmMAU3s61 
— Nick Eagland (@nickeagland) March 9, 2017 
Officer asked me to wait for them to cover windows as undercover drug detectives inside. Said part of warrant execution working w/ Toronto.
— Nick Eagland (@nickeagland) March 9, 2017 

Police were seen raiding Cannabis Culture stores in several cities on Thursday. Vancouver police said its officers were carrying out search warrants in the city to help Toronto police with an investigation.
Vancouver Mayor Gregor Robertson’s staff said neither the mayor nor VPD would be commenting as the operation was being led by Toronto police.
Toronto police said in a release that 11 search warrants were being executed in Toronto, the Hamilton area and Vancouver as part of a project targeting marijuana dispensaries. They said details on charges would be posted when available.
About a dozen Vancouver police officers began executing a raid at Marc Emery’s Cannabis Culture at 307 West Hastings Street at around 8 a.m.
Police also raided Cannabis Culture in Ottawa this morning, two weeks after the Bank Street shop opened with a promise to sell marijuana to anyone over 19.
Fifth man taken into custody at Cannabis Culture. pic.twitter.com/PrVdRjOi8Y 
— Jacquie Miller (@JacquieAMiller) March 9, 2017 

The Vancouver couple’s chain of dispensaries — Cannabis Culture — has at least three stores in Toronto and four locations in Vancouver, selling to anyone aged 19 and over, without membership or medical requirements. 
There are about 20 Cannabis Culture shops across the country in B.C., Ontario and Quebec, although Emery has said it’s hard to keep count because the stores frequently open and close due to police raids. They also sell pot paraphernalia — pipes, vaporizers and other products — on their Cannabis Culture website. 
Social media users reported that Cannabis Culture shops in Toronto and Hamilton were also visited by police. 
@CannabisCulture your Queen broadview shop is full of cops pic.twitter.com/5Vo7t8mKgn 
— Sunny J (@socialdynamo) March 9, 2017 

Victoria-based cannabis lawyer Kirk Tousaw, who has known the Emerys for several years called the arrests a “national disgrace.” 
“That we continue to waste resources and ruin lives in the pursuit of the futile goals of cannabis prohibition is immoral and a national disgrace,” he said. 
Vancouver marijuana advocate Dana Larsen, a founding member of the Marijuana Party of Canada and former editor of Emery’s Cannabis Culture magazine, was just learning about the news when contacted by Postmedia.
Related Prince and princess of pot are expanding their dispensary empire, whether it’s legal or not Montreal police raid newly opened Cannabis Culture marijuana dispensaries, arrest ‘Prince of Pot’ Marc Emery Brian Hutchinson: Legalizing marijuana will mean nothing in Vancouver, where people act like it already happened It was his understanding that the Emerys were on their way to Spain, to attend Spannabis, when arrested. 
“To me it is just another example of what we will be facing for years to come,” he said. “Trudeau could fix this by putting in his legislation … by doing what he said he was going to do.”
The federal government is moving to legalize marijuana, but Prime Minister Justin Trudeau emphasized late last year that the current laws exist.
Marc Emery, the self-styled “Prince of Pot,” was arrested at one of his new Montreal dispensaries in December and charged with drug trafficking.
Police forces across the country have been raiding pot shops in recent months and charging owners with trafficking-related offences.
